name: (2Z)-(3,4-dimethoxy-5-oxofuran-2(5H)-ylidene)ethanal
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1499

name: (2Z)-(3,4-dimethoxy-5-oxofuran-2(5H)-ylidene)ethanal
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1499
Reason: The target compound is a furan derivative with additional substituents. The basic furan unit has a melting point of -85.6. Multiple functional groups affect the melting point: two aldehyde groups (+40 each due to polar carbonyl group and hydrogen bonding capabilities), two methoxy groups (+30 each due to additional van der Waals forces and dipoles from oxygen), and conjugation within the ring system (+25 from increased planarity and molecular stability). Note that these are estimates, and the effects can be non-linear or interdependent; however, the melting point is likely raised significantly from the plain furan unit due to these combined effects.

name: (2Z)-(3,4-dimethoxy-5-oxofuran-2(5H)-ylidene)ethanal
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1499
Reason: The molecule in discussion is a furan derivative, and other functional groups are attached to this furan core. The standard melting point of furan is -85.6 degrees Celsius. Each aldehyde group present contributes to an increase in the melting point due to the polar carbonyl group and potential for hydrogen bonding; the increment is added for the two aldehyde groups, assuming +40 degrees Celsius for each. Each methoxy group (–OCH3) contributes more weak van der Waals forces and has a polar bond which probably further increases the melting point; an estimate of +30 degrees Celsius for each of the two methoxy groups is added. The conjugation within the furan ring system adds to the planarity and stability of the molecule, which is associated with a higher melting point; an increase of +25 is estimated for the overall conjugation effect. Adding these incremental values to the base furan melting point should provide a rough estimate of the actual melting point.
